intro: Mystacidium taeniophylloides, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the family Viscaceae. It grows on a variety of host trees, primarily in the southern United States and parts of Mexico. The plant has small, elliptical leaves that are usually arranged alternately along its stems. Its flowers are unisexual, with separate male and female flowers on the same plant, and it produces small, fleshy berries as fruit. The plant's parasitic nature allows it to derive water and nutrients from its host, while also photosynthesizing to some extent.
